message.content: This question is about the effect of exertion on an object that is in motion. When an exertion is applied against the intended direction of the object, it will oppose the motion. This is due to the concept of Newton's third law of motion, which states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. Option (A) is incorrect because melting is not related to exertion on an object in motion. Option (C) is incorrect because exertion against the intended direction will actually slow down the object, not speed it up. Option (D) is unrelated to the concept of exertion on an object in motion.

This question is about Newton's laws of motion. According to Newton's first law of motion, an object will continue to move in its original direction unless acted upon by an external force. This external force that acts against the object's intended direction is called opposition. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) oppose it. 

Option (A) is incorrect because melting is a physical change caused by heat, which is not related to the exertion on a moving object going against its intended direction. Option (C) is incorrect because the exertion against the intended direction would actually slow down the object, not speed it up. Option (D) is incorrect because burning is a chemical reaction that is not related to the exertion against an object's intended direction.

This question requires basic knowledge about the laws of motion. According to Newton's first law of motion, an object in motion tends to stay in motion unless acted upon by an external force. When an exertion is applied on a thing that is going against its intended direction, it will oppose the motion and try to slow it down or bring it to a stop. Option (A) is incorrect because melting is not related to the motion of an object. Option (C) is incorrect because applying an exertion against the intended direction would typically slow down the object, not speed it up. Option (D) is incorrect because burning is not related to the motion of an object.

This question is asking about the result of applying force to an object that is moving in the opposite direction of the force. Based on fundamental principles of motion and Newton's laws of motion, when an exertion is applied against an object's intended direction of motion, it will oppose the motion of the object. This is because of the concept of inertia, which states that an object will resist changes in its motion. Option (A) is incorrect because melting is not applicable in this scenario. Option (C) is also incorrect because applying force against the intended direction of motion will actually slow down the object, not speed it up. Option (D) is unrelated to motion and not applicable in this scenario.

This question requires knowledge about the principles of motion and forces. When an exertion is applied against the intended direction of motion, it creates a force that opposes the motion. This is known as friction. Option (A) is incorrect because melting requires heat, which is not mentioned in the question. Option (C) is incorrect because if something is going against its intended direction, applying a force in that direction would actually slow it down. Option (D) is incorrect because burning is not related to the principles of motion and forces.

This question is testing our knowledge of Newton's first law of motion, also known as the law of inertia. According to this law, an object will continue to move in the same direction with the same speed unless acted upon by an external force. When an exertion is applied to an object in motion, it will oppose the object's intended direction. This means that it will act as a force opposing the motion of the object, making it harder for the object to continue in its intended direction. Options (A), (C), and (D) are incorrect because they do not align with the principles of motion and inertia.

This question is related to Newton's laws of motion. According to Newton's first law, an object in motion will remain in motion unless acted upon by an external force. When an exertion or force is applied in a direction opposite to the object's intended motion, it will oppose the object's motion. Option (A) is incorrect because melting is not related to exerting force on a moving object. Option (C) is incorrect because exerting force against the object's intended direction will slow it down, not speed it up. Option (D) is incorrect because burning is unrelated to the concept of exertion and motion.

When an exertion is applied to a thing that is going against its intended direction of motion, it will oppose its motion. This is based on Newton's First Law of Motion, which states that an object in motion will stay in motion in a straight line at a constant speed unless acted upon by an external force. Option (A) is incorrect because melting is not related to an object's motion. Option (C) is incorrect because the exertion is going against the intended direction of motion, so it would actually slow it down rather than speed it up. Option (D) is incorrect because burning is unrelated to the object's motion.

This question is testing our understanding of the concept of force and motion. When an exertion is applied to something that is already in motion, it will oppose its motion. This is based on Newton's first law of motion, which states that an object in motion will stay in motion with the same speed and direction unless acted upon by an external force. Option (A) is incorrect because melting is not related to motion or exertion. Option (C) is incorrect because applying an exertion in the same direction as the motion would speed it up, not when going against the intended direction. Option (D) is incorrect because burning is not related to motion or exertion.

When an exertion is applied to a moving object in the opposite direction of its intended motion, it will oppose the object's motion. This is because the exertion creates a force that acts against the object's motion, resulting in a decrease in speed or even bring it to a stop. Option (A) is incorrect because melting is not related to exertion on an object. Option (C) is also incorrect because opposing the motion will slow it down, not speed it up. Option (D) is incorrect because burning is not related to exertion on an object.

This question requires knowledge of Newton's laws of motion. Newton's first law states that an object at rest will stay at rest, and an object in motion will stay in motion with the same speed and in the same direction, unless acted upon by an unbalanced force. When an exertion is applied on a thing that is going against its intended direction, it will oppose the motion and act as an unbalanced force. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) oppose it. Options (A), (C), and (D) are incorrect because they do not describe the effect of an exertion on an object's motion.
